unnormalised: Someone asked me: "Is flying Indigo like taking a really fancy auto-rickshaw?" Honestly, as an Indian, I feel uniquely qualified to answer this. So, buckle up, bhaiyo aur behno, because here’s the brutally honest truth.
normalised: Someone asked me: "Is flying Indigo like taking a really fancy auto-rickshaw?" Honestly, as an Indian, I feel uniquely qualified to answer this. So, buckle up, bhaiyo aur behno, because here's the brutally honest truth.

unnormalised: First off, the seating. Indigo touts legroom, right? Well, my nanaji's bullock cart had more legroom, okay maybe not, but you get my drift. It's enough that you are not touching the seat in front of you, if that helps. You feel like one of those chickens packed together for transport, but hey, at least you're getting somewhere, right? And instead of bumpy rural roads, you're soaring 30,000 ft in the air. Small mercies.

And instead of bumpy rural roads, you're soaring thirty thousand feet in the air. Small mercies.

unnormalised: The food, oh the food! You know that stale sandwich you find at the back of your fridge after a week? Indigo's food is… slightly better. Think of it as a culinary adventure, where the adventure is trying to identify what exactly you’re eating. Veggie puff? Chicken wrap? Mysterious substance in bread? Who knows! Embrace the mystery! Bring snacks, lots of them. Like, enough to feed a small village. Trust me on this one. I always bring two packets of lays and a bottle of water.

unnormalised: The on-time performance, they claim is their USP, but the flights are more "Indian Standard Time" than punctual. IST as we lovingly call it, is a theoretical time zone where time is merely a suggestion. The pilot might channel his inner Rajinikanth and land early, or you might spend an extra 2 hrs circling over Delhi because of "technical difficulties." Who knows? That's part of the fun! Think of it as a surprise delay, but I usually manage to finish an entire web series during the delays.

Think of it as a surprise delay, but I usually manage to finish an entire web series during the delays.

unnormalised: And let's not forget the announcements. The crew is always cheerful. Like, unnervingly cheerful. Even when turbulence is making your chai threaten to escape your cup, they're beaming and telling you to "enjoy your flight." I think they're powered by some kind of optimism-based fuel, which, frankly, I need to bottle and sell.

unnormalised: But here's the thing, even with all its quirks, Indigo gets you from point A to point B, often at a price that won't require you to sell your kidney. It's reliable in its own chaotic way. It’s like that friend who is always late, but always shows up in the end. So, is it a fancy auto-rickshaw? Maybe not fancy, but definitely an auto-rickshaw in the sky. So next time you want to travel from Delhi to Mumbai for ₹3000, book a ticket and embrace the chaos. You will get there in the end.

unnormalised: Just remember to pack those snacks, prepone your expectations, and maybe, just maybe, you'll actually enjoy the ride. Happy flying! And remember kids, turbulence is just a free roller coaster ride. Remember to follow all safety norms instructed by our unnervingly cheerful staff. Jai Hind!
